												God, where do I begin. This game is a masterpiece from head to toe. First was the intro, a beautifully crafted song and music piece that the likes of Beethoven could only dream of. Next, was the plot. Never have I seen a more complex yet amazing plot, filled with twists and turns from the beginning to the end. The characters were very deep and I was involved with them within moments. The gameplay was an amazing system I have never seen before, with so many different options of play it was amazing. The graphics are beyond next-gen, like something you may see on the Playstation 6 if you're lucky. The soundtrack and sound design are possibly the lowest point, yet they would still get an easy 8/10. But overall, this was a beautiful game that I don't think any could parallel it for generations, and it was an amazing emotional trip for me as well. I was crying, laughing, mad, concerned, surprised, none of my emotions went untouched. And to think, all of this for free. Amazing. Would I recommend this game? To anyone with an IQ above -7, I say hell yes. Do it, or your life will not be complete.

												The Annual Lazytown Spring Smash Potluck was tomorrow or so Robbie had been informed. It was something of an explanation to how Robbie had ended up here in his life, walking along with Sportacus with bags of groceries. He didn't understand it but it was an explanation.To begin with, Sportacus was not particularly good at walking alongside someone while carrying groceries. Point of fact he wasn't particularly good at carrying groceries at all. In order to flippity flippity flop around town, he needed his hands free, and that left Robbie trailing along behind him, lugging cloth grocery bags loaded with supplies.This is what Robbie's life had been reduced to; carrying someone else's groceries. Strike that, carrying someone else's groceries and listening to that person explain what they were going to do with them. Some sort of fruit salad, Robbie had gathered, not that he was about to ask."â€¦of course you don't have to eat it, but maybe you could try it? I think you'll like it, maybe, andâ€¦"Groceries. Sports candy. All in the bags, along with one small cake, delicately frosted in white and purple icing, for him alone. Although knowing the local brats Robbie was likely to be suckered into sharing at least some of it. That blond kid was particularly good at sorrowful, pleading eyes when it came to sweets.Sportacus jogged back to him, still rambling on about what he was going to mangle his fruits into for the potluck and utterly unbothered that Robbie only grunted in reply. "â€¦and I was thinking about making those little sandwiches, the kids like them last timeâ€¦"He'd never have done this before, Robbie thought sourly. He'd never even been to The Annual Lazytown Spring Smash Potluck; he'd always managed to sleep through the blasted thing. How was it Sportacus always managed to get him to do things like this?Shopping for fruits and veg, no, get it right, shopping for sports candy, going along with Sportacus for potlucks, for crying out loud. Worse, they were going back to Robbie's bunker with all of it and Robbie wasn't even entirely sure why. Yes, yes, he had some kitchen space cleared out now, one section of his counter marked off with masking tape that meant none of his machine parts were allowed to enter the sterile area. And yes, he had somehow grown a collection of knifes and utensils and bowls; the blasted things seemed to have sprouted from nowhere and now they lived in the masking tape zone.It still seemed like it would be easier to make whatever it was Sportacus was babbling about in his airship, but that would mean Robbie would have to climb up a ladder carrying bags and that was a level of no that couldn't be properly expressed in words.At his bunker, Robbie set down the bags with a sigh, only half-listening to Sportacus yammering on about fruit salad and sandwiches and whatever else was flittering through his mind.Why did he do these things for Sportacus, Robbie wondered idly. It made Sportacus happy, true, butâ€¦it made Sportacus happy. Something about that clicked in Robbie's head, like a faulty gear suddenly snapping back into place. It made him happy, it delighted him when Robbie did things with him. Shopping for his sports candy, going to the Annual Lazytown Spring Smash Potluck, tinkering around with small inventions in the park while half-watching Sportacus playing with the children. It made Sportacus happy and when he smiled at Robbie, it felt likeâ€¦it feltâ€¦well. Sportacus being happy made Robbie happy.Realization came with the force of a smack between the eyes. Sportacus was humming to himself, sorting through the bags and making neat piles out of the fruit and he was here in Robbie's bunker doing this because Robbie wanted him here."Sportacus, I think I'm in love with you," Robbie blurted and he couldn't have held the words back with both hands."Hmm? Oh, thank you. I love you, too," Sportacus said absently, studying the row of bundled vegetables and fruit as though he were planning out a schematic of health. Probably he was.That...was not the right reaction. Robbie blinked at him, mouth agape, and then demanded, "Didn't you hear me? I said I love you."Sportacus glanced at him, "Yes, of course I heard you. I said thank you, didn't I? And I love you, too."Robbie stared. "But--""Don't tell me you're only just realizing this now. We've been going out for weeks." Sportacus turned to look fully at him, setting the loaf of organic stone-ground wheat bread aside.Robbie straightened instantly, looking down his nose at Sportacus who had the audacity to look amused. "Of course not!" Robbie scoffed, "I just realized I hadn't said it out loud."Sportacus's smile gentled. He rose up on his toes and pressed a light kiss to Robbie's mouth, hardly more than a peck. "Of course you have. I always hear I love you when you're speaking." He turned back to the splayed vegetation. "Now, do you want to help me slice these or did you have a project you wanted to work on?""Iâ€¦" Robbie faltered. He did have a project he could be working on and he was making a new outfit for the potluck because there was no point in attending an event if you weren't prepared to dress for it. Sportacus was already peeling the bananas, slicing them into even chunks as if it didn't matter to him in the least what Robbie choseâ€¦and why would it. Apparently, he knew how everyone in the room felt before even they did."I can slice them." Robbie washed his hands before gingerly taking the little green carton of strawberries. His slices weren't as even as Sportacus and sometimes he got little pieces of the leaf in it but he managed the entire carton.Sportacus smiled at him, soft and sweet, when Robbie handed over his uneven strawberry chunks and added them to the bowl. "Thank you, Robbie, these are perfect."Not perfect, not at all, but Sportacus was still smiling, humming to himself, and he didn't so much as glance up when Robbie started slicing the grapes to add to the bowl. They were making fruit salad together and tomorrow they would be at the Annual Lazytown Spring Smash Potluck together and it would be everything that Robbie dreaded it would be. And everything he hoped it would be.Maybe, just maybe, he could hear 'I love you' when Sportacus spoke, too.

												You and your sisters are running a Puppy Rescue Center. Each has a responsibility. Barbie is in charge of doing the actual recue of each puppy in the neighborhood on her bike. You play as her and you get a set of objectives that must be completed. As you progress you play as all the sisters as you work on the objectives in order to get the puppy adopted out.General GameplayYou get a phone call on your cell phone and this is how each rescue begins! Eventually you get a map of the town. You are suppose to get on your bike and follow the arrow which guides you roughly where to go. Keep in mind that sometimes it points to an area that you can't ride your bike into. Once you find the puppy you must sometimes are required to lure the puppy to you by watching for what the puppy needs on screen.Rescue CenterOnce you are able to pick up the puppy you bring it back to the rescue center. (You then play as Skipper; Barbies sister) The first thing you have to do is check for a microchip using the scanner, (all this is automatic) if there is none you will be prompted to name the puppy yourself. After that you play minigames including removing fleas in which you get rewarded with 10 bones. Finally the puppy is sent to 1 of 3 kennels, eventually being able to earn 2 more at 400 bones each. Kennel#6 will cost 500 bones!Rescue Center- KennelOnce the puppy is in the kennel there are a series of objectives you must complete. An Example would be training the puppy in a quick time event. In this event for example you are told which buttons you press at what time in order to perform the requested performance in that course event.The puppy needs to be 100% rested before you can move onto the next objective. The last of the objectives is getting the puppy adopted. Gameplay: Breakdown The 6 objectives in order are: Note you do 1 in each only and are random for each puppy!#1: Finding the puppy by going through the town. An example of a place the puppy can be is a construction zone.#2: Returning to the shelter with puppy OR sometimes you will be prompted with(Puppy Rescue) Earn Trust: You must Coaz the puppy to come out of hiding.Puppy Rescue- Earn Trust A Screenshot of Barbie and Her Sisters Puppy RescueBy: (â™¥) Pink Lily#3: (Puppy Treatment) Vaccination / Remove Fleas Puppy Treatment- Remove Fleas A Screenshot of Barbie and Her Sisters Puppy RescueBy: (â™¥) Pink LilyNote: You play as skipper in puppy treatment.#4: (Puppy Training) Agility Training / ObedienceNote: You play as Stacie in Puppy Training.#5: (Puppy Grooming) Bath / Clip Nails / Brush TeethPuppy Grooming- Clip Nails A Screenshot of Barbie and Her Sisters Puppy RescueBy: (â™¥) Pink LilyNote: You play as Chelsea in grooming the puppies.#6: (Puppy Adoption) Graduation. 												Janken, (Rock-Paper-Scissors for you Gaijins) is a competition that demands the utmost of determination and skill. Hosting endless layers of mindgames upon mindgames behind its deceivingly simple ruleset, it is not an activity to be partaken by the simple-minded. So imagine my surprise and delight when I would find such a game to be offered on a non-Japanese service such as Steam.Unlike in countries with inferior cultures (take the United States for example with its barbarous sports like Football and Rugby where those primitive apes thoughtlessly throw themselves at each other. I imagine it is due to the resulting brain damage that the East has evolved to be more intelligent than the West), where it is treated as a mere childrenâ€™s game, Janken is an artform in Japan, as obvious as it should be through the likes of manga such as "Kaiji"and "Liar Game" (Ignore the simpletons that recommend you to simply â€œwatch the animeâ€. Their brains, likely atrophied by years of Transformers and Superhero flicks, cannot comprehend that absorbing both is integral to the artistsâ€™ intended experience).In fact, I think the only thing that would make this game better is if it were made by the Japanese. They would take it a step beyond what the Western developers have created by tailoring a deep and intricately woven backstory for each character. The main character would be brooding and mysterious, if only due to his troubled past which will be revealed over the course of the campaign. Rocky would have had a rough childhood, having been teased all his life for his genetic deformity caused by the accident that lost him both of his parents. Randy would have grown up in the slums, and would have slowly risen to the top through sheer will and determination. And of course the girl would have been a childhood friend of the main character who made a promise to one day marry him. With such modifications, the game could possibly exceed â€œG-senjou no Maou - The Devil on G-Stringâ€ as the greatest game on Steam (a nod to my fellow G-senjou no Maou enthusiasts), but I digress.I have seen several criticisms of the game containing only a single player campaign. These cancerous philistines are everything wrong with the state of Western gaming. A multiplayer experience cannot provide the tempestuous rollercoaster of emotional highs and lows that a precariously crafted single-player game can. I am immensely grateful that the Japanese industry does not so easily succumb to the demands of the degenerate masses and refuses to arbitrarily add multiplayer into games that clearly donâ€™t need it.In either case, the developers at Wholetone Games have proven themselves sufficiently competent by expertly building upon the existing Janken formula (a task I previously thought impossible). Through careful placement of strategic combo moves, players have to put infinitely more thought into their turn (a concept that may be difficult for our Western counterparts to comprehend). 												I must say I was skeptical when downloading that game.I was searching for some game that was cheap or even free, which wasn't a big killer for my disc space and I came across this amazing game.The story:You are playing as the protagonist, the former Rock Paper Scissor champion and you must fight your way back to the throne. On your way, you must beat various strategic geniuses.The Gameplay:You are playing a game called "Rock Paper Scissors" to regain your title as champion.Rock-paper-scissors is a zero-sum hand game usually played between two people, in which each player simultaneously forms one of three shapes with an outstretched hand. These shapes are "rock" (a simple fist), "paper" (a flat hand), and "scissors" (a fist with the index and middle fingers together forming a V). The game has only three possible outcomes other than a tie: a player who decides to play rock will beat another player who has chosen scissors ("rock crushes scissors") but will lose to one who has played paper ("paper covers rock"); a play of paper will lose to a play of scissors ("scissors cut paper"). If both players throw the same shape, the game is tied and is usually immediately replayed to break the tie.There is also some special combo moves you can do to higher your chances of winning.My conclusion:After hours of playing, I can gladly recommend this game to all of my friends and family and I think everyone should have tried it at least once. 												The trailer and screenshots absolutely do an injustice to this masterpiece. Never have I witnessed a work of art as entertaining as this video game. The plot is an emotional rollercoaster from beginning to end. Without spoiling any important plot points, you play as an ex-rock paper scissors champion who has fallen from glory. After winning countless championships, the champ feels hollow on the inside, resorting to fruitiously spending his victory money on high-class drugs and expensive alcohol. The champ falls further and further down the hole known as substance abuse until eventually, our hero loses his wife and two children in a car accident. The champ feels truly worthless at this point, quitting rock paper scissors tournaments and losing his home. Homeless, wifeless, childless, and broken, the champ decides to enlist in the military. After a four year term in the middle-east, the champ learns first-hand the atrocities of war. Ashamed of the horrors he committed by the orders of his commanding officer, the champ comes back to America to rekindle his relationship with the last thing he holds dear to his heart, rock paper scissors. The champ must face opposition and hardships no man before him has faced, all in the name of rock paper scissors. It is time for the champ to reclaim his throne. Truly a diamond in the ruff. 10/10, a masterpiece.

												"Rock Paper Scissors CHAMPIONNNN!"I have heard those words before.Hope imposed from the title, I wondered if this could be the RPS simulation all the pros had been waiting for. Sadly.... this is NOT the case. I seriously regret telling my local RPS club I would look into this software (I scoff at the thought this could "teach" an aspiring athlete). Simply, the core gameplay is plagued, one could not count the issues. Yes, even with the extra fingers of a siamese twin.Most notable is this shovelware's lazy reliance on RNG, not unlike many lowly RPS sims. If the devs stopped there it could pass as a free (albeit ugly) timewaster, but ASSwHOLEtone GAYmes decide to trash a classic with some "modern" additions. I simply cannot fathom why they decided on ommiting a "classic" mode without the "Streaks", "Score" or Health Bars.Much has already been said about this title's aesthetic. I personally like the look (I'm no graphic design designer by any means). I even thought the song was catchy. However, not one RPS enthusiast I showed this to could hold in any vomit."Rock Paper Scissors '''''''Champion'''''''''" lacks, like a corpse without a coffin.You will find no simple AI assessing moves, nor making a typical guess (Noob? Beat them at the start with paper).In case you didn't know, pro players spend hours upon hours honing their knowledge of "tells". Nowhere in this game will you see anything of the sort. Hear me out plebs, this is important:Thumb positioning in the pre-game fist could be a giveaway for rock. (If my suggestions are taken onboard, keep this to the easy difficulty, anyone in a legit "championship" knows (some may even bluff/double bluff a new facewith it).The animations could be given more frames, and hint to the moves early on, this allows a predictive counter, providing one can  move milliseconds late. The current control scheme is set out much too rigid for anything of the sort, which is a pity. I have seen many people bluff rock, only to snap out two scissorblades of fingers (a semi legal, but respectable technique)."Rock Paper Scissors" is much more like a duel in a Western than this game's casual clicking. You will find no depth or redeeming value here, what I have witnessed deserves a fetid 0/10However, I will be analysing the game in the further weeks. Current scorn aside, this abomination could be quite purposeful in some sly "modern art", a topic to which I hold much enthusiasm. I can imagine it's context for satire of our society post Hilary Clinton's inauguration. Therefore, I will be scanning this game for twists, hidden messages, or alternate endings.This review will be updated should the onion have more layers. Cutting deeper I just leak tears of dissapointment, but I want to prove or disprove any improvement. Maybe this is like the tasty fried onion in a hotdog. God forbid I bite this onion raw.Adieu
